item.title: Uncertain future for ISS astronauts Wilmore and Williams: Nasa weighs SpaceX vs Boeing Starliner
item.description: NASA remains undecided on whether to keep astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams at the ISS due to issues with Boeing's Starliner capsule. The astronauts might extend their stay until February 2025, potentially returning aboard SpaceX's Dragon. Boeing faced setbacks during the mission, including thruster malfunctions and helium leaks, prompting further tests in space.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Google celebrates India's Independence Day with this special Doodle
item.description: On India's 78th Independence Day, Google featured a doodle by Vrinda Zaveri, celebrating iconic Indian architecture adorned in national colors. The doodle honored freedom fighters and highlighted Independence Day celebrations, including flag-raising ceremonies and cultural events. Google offered best wishes to the nation, continuing its tradition of creating special doodles for significant global occasions.
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: Will Prince Harry and Meghan Markle’s Sussexes titles survive? 'The Balmoral gathering isn’t just a summer holiday,' insider warns
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: High-stakes talks in Doha: Can US and Middle Eastern allies secure Gaza Hostage release and ceasefire?
item.description: Senior officials from the US, Qatar, Egypt, and Israel met in Doha for crucial discussions to finalize a hostage release and ceasefire agreement for Gaza. The gathered leaders sought to de-escalate Middle Eastern tensions and avert a larger regional conflict, amid threats from Iran and Hezbollah. President Biden viewed the agreement as critical to reducing broader war risks.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Ukraine says advance into Russia 'going well': New evacuation hotline and military strikes highlight escalation
item.description: Ukraine's forces advanced in Russia's Kursk region, creating a buffer zone to protect Ukraine's borders. President Zelenskyy announced plans for military commandant offices, and a hotline for residents wishing to evacuate to Ukraine. Meanwhile, Russia ordered evacuations in response but struggled to dislodge Ukrainian troops, despite President Putin's vows.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US Navy unveils longest-range missile: Will AIM-174B be a game-changer in Indo-Pacific tensions?
item.description: The US Navy deployed the AIM-174B long-range air-to-air missile in the Indo-Pacific to counter China's aerial supremacy. This missile, operational since July, significantly extends reach compared to previous missiles. It allows US jets to keep Chinese threats at bay, protect key assets, and strike high-value targets from afar, altering the strategic balance in the region.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Columbia University President Minouche Shafik resigns amid protests and national scrutiny

item.title: 'Start writing that way': Biden demands media praise, critics accuse US president of manipulating coverage
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Teen falls asleep during courtroom field trip, ends up in cuffs and jail clothes
item.description: A Detroit judge put a 16-year-old girl in jail clothes and handcuffs during a field trip as a lesson on courtroom decorum. Judge Kenneth King criticized her attitude and threatened juvenile detention to make her understand courtroom behavior. The incident drew criticism from The Greening of Detroit, who organized the trip, deeming the judge's methods unacceptable.

item.title: Biden 'most angry' with Nancy Pelosi, hasn't spoken yet; 'frustrated' with Obama
item.description: Weeks after exiting the race that he was adamant to keep on fighting, US president Joe Biden is still coming to terms with what happened behind his back -- 'engineered' mainly by Barack Obama, Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer. But his feeling for the three of them are different, Politico reported citing Biden's close aides. Biden is angry with Nancy Pelosi, frustrated with Barack Obama and miffed at Schumer.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Donald Trump said he would go to Venezuela if he loses to Kamala but...
item.description: In his interview with Elon Musk, Trump said he would go to Venezuela if he loses the election. “If something happens with this election, which would be a horror show, we’ll meet the next time in Venezuela,” Trump said. It was a swipe at Kamala Harris as Trump said Venezuela with is in the middle of a political crisis over the re-election of Nicholas Maduro will be a far safer place than the US if Kamala Harris becomes the president.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Atlanta joins Bengal in 'Reclaim the night' protest against Kolkata's RG Kar rape-murder horror
item.description: The social media call to women to come out on the streets at night to reclaim their space in protest against the rape-murder horror of Kolkata's RG Kar Medical Hospital reached far beyond Bengal as the Bengalis in Atlanta have decided to join the protest seeking justice for RG Kar incident. The protest will be near Global Mall from 6.30 ET onwards, one of the organizers informed. The protest will not be held under any banner -- just a spontaneous coming together of the Bengalis in Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Ukraine's unexpected advance into Russian territory: How the events unfolded
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Disgusting': British influencer slammed for putting underwear between breads in supermarket
item.description: A video of a woman taking off her underwear and then keeping it amid breads at a supermarket has drawn flak and disgust of social media. According to reports, the woman in the viral challenge video was Chole Lopez, an English influencer, who claimed to have done this bizarre act on camera as part of a challenge.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Harris campaign editing news headlines in her favour within Google search ads: Report
item.description: Kamala Harris' campaign was editing news headlines in Google ads to create a favorable image without news websites' consent. Google stated the ads did not breach policies, although a technical glitch made some ads appear lack disclosures. Brands like CNN, USA Today, and NPR were unaware their links were used this way.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
